descriptions.content:
Non-volitional verbs imply non-controllable processes that do not depend on the subject’s volition, and are compatible neither with intentional auxiliaries nor with imperative markers. With non-volitional verbs, non-intentional auxiliaries such as བྱུང་ or སོང་ must be used.

Some basic examples of non-volitional verbs are:

  • མཐོང་བྱུང་། “I saw.”
  • དྲག་བྱུང་། “I recovered.”

The following forms are incorrect because they combine a non-volitional verb with an intentional auxiliary:

  • *མཐོང་པ་ཡིན་
  • *དྲག་པ་ཡིན་

The following imperatives are also incorrect:

  • *མཐོང་ཤིག
  • *དྲག་ཤིག

There are, however, some non-volitional verbs that imply a certain degree of control, such as “to lose” or “to go to sleep”; it is possible to make imperative forms of these verbs.
